metadata.case_name: Maharaj Jagat Bahadur Singh v. Badri Prasad Seth

facts.text: Appellant Maharaj Jagat Bahadur Singh is owner of premises known as Ranzor Hall in Simla.
Respondent Badri Prasad Seth is tenant in occupation of premises running Revoli cinema/theatre.

On or about April 12, 1956, Executive Engineer, Simla Provincial Division, inspected cinema building on behalf of Licensing Authority (Deputy Commissioner, Simla) and noted six defects, including 'the right hand pillar of the screen has cracked and has gone out of plumb'.
Existence of defects communicated to respondent and Municipal Committee, Simla.
Respondent wrote to appellant on April 17, 1956, suggesting defect in pillar be removed before June 1956 when rains commence.
Respondent removed other minor defects but, getting no reply from appellant, wrote again on September 1, 1956, asking to repair pillar early to avoid mishap, estimating cost around Rs. 5000/-.
Appellant took no action for some time.

On September 24, 1956, East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 amended, inserting clause (iii) in s.13(3)(a) entitling landlord to possession for building work at instance of local authority or if unsafe/unfit.

On April 9, 1956, appellant wrote to President, Simla Municipal Committee, asking for inspection of pillar by Executive Engineer for opinion on dangerous condition and action under s.116 Punjab Municipal Act, 1911.
On October 30, 1956, Secretary, Municipal Committee, Simla, wrote to respondent requiring repairs to right hand pillar within 15 days under ss.113 and 114 Punjab Municipal Act, 1911.

In November 1956, Municipal Committee had pillar inspected by Executive Engineer, Simla Central Division, who suggested two end walls/pillars supporting screen beams were cracked and must be replaced by thicker walls.
Municipal Committee considered report and concluded precautionary measure was to fill doorway in pillar with masonry to make solid block.
On April 11, 1957, Municipal Committee wrote to appellant asking to fill doorway with masonry to make pillar solid block (modification of earlier notice).
On December 1, 1956, appellant applied to Rent Controller under s.13 Act for possession to replace end walls supporting screen beams by thicker walls.
Rent Controller held case covered by cl.(iii) s.13(3)(a), ordered possession.

Respondent appealed to District Judge under s.15 Act; District Judge held notices manipulated post-amendment, not bona fide need, repairs minor (fill doorway), Executive Engineer inspected June 8, 1957 and found pillar satisfactorily repaired; allowed appeal, dismissed application.
Revision to Punjab High Court under s.15(5) Act (Civil Revision No.27/1958); K.L. Gosain J. treated as under CPC s.115, affirmed District Judge findings, dismissed on May 21, 1958.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.
Executive Engineer, Central P.W.D., inspected on June 8, 1957 per court directions, satisfied pillar satisfactorily repaired.
Rent Controller ordered vacation by September 25, 1957.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant-landlord bona fide required the building to be vacated by tenant to carry out building work directed by Municipal Committee under cl.(iii) of s.13(3)(a) of East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949.
Scope of revision under s.15(5) of the Act vis-a-vis s.115 CPC.
Whether post-application facts (like modified notice and repair completion) can be considered.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant bona fide requires building for repairs to pillar/end walls as directed by Municipal Committee notices under ss.113,114 Punjab Municipal Act; case covered by cl.(iii) s.13(3)(a).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 s.13(3)(a)(iii); Punjab Municipal Act, 1911 ss.113,114

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in treating revision as under CPC s.115; s.15(5) Act has wider scope beyond jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 s.15(5); CPC s.115

petitioner_arguments.text: District Judge erred in holding notices manipulated and in considering post-filing facts.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant's claim not bona fide; manipulated notices post-amendment; does not really require vacation as repairs minor (fill doorway), can be done without vacation; already repaired.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 s.13(3)(a)(iii)

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in applying CPC s.115 scope to s.15(5) Act revision, which is wider for legality/propriety, but affirmed District Judge findings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.15(5) Act not confined to jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.(iii) s.13(3)(a) attracted only if landlord 'requires' building vacated for extensive/fundamental repairs impossible with tenant in possession; minor repairs like filling doorway do not qualify.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Emphasis on word 'requires'; scheme/purpose of rent legislation.

court_reasoning.text: District Judge rightly considered post-filing facts (modified notice, repair completion by June 8, 1957 before vacation date Sept 25, 1957) as relevant to when order effective; Controller rejected Engineer testimony insufficiently.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Open to consider facts at time vacation to take effect.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide if notices manipulated; requirement not met as repairs simple, done without vacation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Repairs could be carried out without tenant vacating.

holdings.text: Cl.(iii) s.13(3)(a) applies only to extensive repairs requiring tenant vacation; minor repairs like filling doorway do not.
Post-filing facts relevant if pertaining to time of vacation effect.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs eviction for repairs at local authority instance only if requires vacation; revision scope for legality/propriety.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Municipal Act, 1911
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for Municipal Committee notices requiring repairs.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court wrongly applied its limited jurisdiction scope to Act's revision.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirming High Court and District Judge orders dismissing landlord's application under s.13 Act, holding no bona fide need to vacate for minor repairs already completed.

key_quotes.text: 'requires' ... abundantly clear that cl.(iii) of s.13(3)(a) ... is attracted only when the building work is such that the landlord requires that the building be vacated by the tenant in order to carry out the work ... extensive and fundamental in character.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It was open to the learned District Judge to take into consideration such facts as existed at the time when the order for vacation was to come into effect.
key_quotes.speaker: court
